\(0,1,\dots ,19\) exactly \(50\) times because \(1000=20\times 50\).

Only the \(12\) residues in \(H\) are attainable, so among the
\(20\cdot50=1000\) integers we have

\[
12\text{ residues}\times 50\text{ occurrences}=600
\]

representable numbers.

------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{600}
\]

Let $z_1$, $z_2$, $z_3$, $\dots$, $z_{12}$ be the 12 zeroes of the polynomial $z^{12} - 2^{36}$. For each $j$, let $w_j$ be one of $z_j$ or $iz_j$.  Find the maximum possible value of the real part of
\[\sum_{j = 1}^{12} w_j.\]

The 12 zeros of \(z^{12}-2^{36}\) are the 12‑th roots of \(2^{36}=8^{12}\):

\[
z_k = 8e^{i\pi k/6},\qquad k=0,1,\dots ,11 .
\]

For each zero we may choose either \(z_k\) or \(iz_k\).  
The real part of \(z_k\) is \(8\cos \frac{\pi k}{6}\) and the real part of \(iz_k\) is \(-8\sin \frac{\pi k}{6}\).

To maximise the sum of the real parts we pick for each \(k\) the larger of the two values:

\[
\max\bigl(8\cos \tfrac{\pi k}{6},\; -8\sin \tfrac{\pi k}{6}\bigr)
    = 8\,\max\!\left(\cos\tfrac{\pi k}{6},\,-\sin\tfrac{\pi k}{6}\right).
\]

Compute \(\max(\cos\theta,-\sin\theta)\) for \(\theta=\frac{\pi k}{6}\):

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c}
k & \cos\theta & -\sin\theta & \max   \\\hline
0 & 1          & 0            & 1\\
1 & \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2} & -\tfrac12 & \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}\\
2 & \tfrac12          & -\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}& \tfrac12\\
3 & 0              & -1           & 0\\
4 & -\tfrac12        & -\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}& -\tfrac12\\
5 & -\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2} & -\tfrac12 & -\tfrac12\\
6 & -1             & 0           & 0\\
7 & -\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2} & \tfrac12  & \tfrac12\\
8 & -\tfrac12        & \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}& \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}\\
9 & 0               & 1          & 1\\
10& \tfrac12        & \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}& \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}\\
11& \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}& \tfrac12  & \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}
\end{array}
\]

Summing the maxima gives

\[
1+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}+\frac12+0-\frac12-\frac12+0+\frac12+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}
+1+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}=2+2\sqrt3.
\]

Multiplying by the factor \(8\) (the radius of the roots) yields

\[
8\,(2+2\sqrt3)=16+16\sqrt3.
\]

Thus the greatest possible real part of \(\sum_{j=1}^{12} w_j\) is

\[
\boxed{16+16\sqrt{3}}.
\]
Show that the curve  $x^{3}+3xy+y^{3}=1$  contains only one set of three distinct points,  $A,B,$  and  $C,$  which are the vertices of an equilateral triangle.

\[
x^{3}+3xy+y^{3}=1\qquad(\*)
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Factorisation of the cubic

Because  
\[
x^{3}+y^{3}= (x+y)(x^{2}-xy+y^{2}),
\]
we write  

\[
x^{3}+3xy+y^{3}-1=(x+y)(x^{2}-xy+y^{2})+3xy-1.
\]

Checking \(y=1-x\) shows that \(x+y-1\) is a factor of the left–hand side.  
A division gives  

\[
x^{3}+y^{3}+3xy-1=(x+y-1)\bigl(x^{2}-xy+y^{2}+x+y+1\bigr).  \tag{1}
\]

Thus the real points of the curve are the union of

* the line  
  \[
  L:\quad x+y=1,  \tag{L}
  \]
* the conic (in fact a point)  
  \[
  Q:\quad x^{2}-xy+y^{2}+x+y+1=0. \tag{Q}
  \]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  The conic \(Q\)

Write \(u=x+1,\;v=y+1\).  Then

\[
Q:\;u^{2}+v^{2}-uv=0 .
\]

For real \(u,v\),
\[
u^{2}+v^{2}-uv=\tfrac34(u^{2}+v^{2})+\tfrac14(u-v)^{2}\ge 0
\]
and the equality holds only if \(u=v=0\).  
Hence the only real point of \(Q\) is \((-1,-1)\).

So   \(*\) consists of the straight line \(L\) together with the isolated
point \(C=(-1,-1)\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Where can the vertices of an equilateral triangle lie?

A non‑degenerate triangle cannot have all three vertices on the
line \(L\).  
Since \(Q\) contains only the single point \(C\), an equilateral
triangle on the curve must use \(C\) as one vertex; the other two vertices
must lie on the line \(L\).

Let
\[
A=(a,\,1-a),\qquad B=(b,\,1-b),\qquad a\ne b ,
\]
be the two points on \(L\), and let \(C=(-1,-1)\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Equilateral‑triangle conditions  

The squared distances are

\[
\begin{aligned}
CA^{2}&=(a+1)^{2}+(2-a)^{2}=2a^{2}-2a+5,\\[2mm]
CB^{2}&=(b+1)^{2}+(2-b)^{2}=2b^{2}-2b+5,\\[2mm]
AB^{2}&=(a-b)^{2} + \bigl((1-a)-(1-b)\bigr)^{2}
      =2(a-b)^{2}=2(2a-1)^{2}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The equalities \(CA=CB\) and \(AB=CA\) give

\[
2a^{2}-2a+5 = 2b^{2}-2b+5
           \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
(a-b)(a+b-1)=0 .
\]

Since \(a\neq b\), we have \(a+b=1\).

Now
\[
2(2a-1)^{2}=2a^{2}-2a+5
\]
reduces to
\[
2a^{2}-2a-1=0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
a=\frac{1\pm\sqrt3}{2}.
\]

Thus
\[
b=1-a=\frac{1\mp\sqrt3}{2}.
\]

The two signs produce the same unordered pair \(\{A,B\}\).
Consequently there is a single set of distinct points on the curve
forming an equilateral triangle.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 5.  The unique equilateral triangle

The vertices are

\[
\boxed{\,C=(-1,-1),\;
       A=\Big(\frac{1+\sqrt3}{2},\,\frac{1-\sqrt3}{2}\Big),\;
       B=\Big(\frac{1-\sqrt3}{2},\,\frac{1+\sqrt3}{2}\Big)\,}
\]

A quick check gives

\[
CA=CB=AB=\sqrt6 ,
\]
so the triangle is indeed equilateral.  
Since any other configuration would require three distinct points all on
\(L\) or on \(Q\), which is impossible, the triangle above is *the* one.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\text{Hence the curve }x^{3}+3xy+y^{3}=1\text{ contains exactly one set of three distinct points that are the vertices of an equilateral triangle.}
\]

A heavy nucleus $N$, at rest, undergoes fission $N \rightarrow P+Q$, where $P$ and $Q$ are two lighter nuclei. Let $\delta=M_{N}-M_{P}-M_{Q}$, where $M_{P}, M_{Q}$ and $M_{N}$ are the masses of $P$, $Q$ and $N$, respectively. $E_{P}$ and $E_{Q}$ are the kinetic energies of $P$ and $Q$, respectively. The speeds of $P$ and $Q$ are $v_{P}$ and $v_{Q}$, respectively. If $c$ is the speed of light, which of the following statement(s) is(are) correct?

(A) $E_{P}+E_{Q}=c^{2} \delta$

(B) $E_{P}=\left(\frac{M_{P}}{M_{P}+M_{Q}}\right) c^{2} \delta$

(C) $\frac{v_{P}}{v_{Q}}=\frac{M_{Q}}{M_{P}}$

(D) The magnitude of momentum for $P$ as well as $Q$ is $c \sqrt{2 \mu \delta}$, where $\mu=\frac{M_{P} M_{Q}}{\left(M_{P}+M_{Q}\right)}$

**Answer:  (A), (C) and (D) are correct; (B) is incorrect.**

---

### Why (A) is correct  

Initially the heavy nucleus \(N\) is at rest, so its total energy is simply its rest‑energy

\[
E_{\text i}=M_{N}c^{2}.
\]

After fission the fragments \(P\) and \(Q\) move, each possessing rest‑energy and kinetic energy.  
Energy conservation gives

\[
M_{N}c^{2}=M_{P}c^{2}+E_{P}+M_{Q}c^{2}+E_{Q}
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
E_{P}+E_{Q}=(M_{N}-M_{P}-M_{Q})c^{2}=\delta\,c^{2}.
\]

Hence statement (A) holds.

---

### Why (C) is correct (non‑relativistic limit)

The heavy nucleus is initially at rest, so the total momentum after fission must be zero.  
Thus the magnitudes of the fragment momenta are equal:

\[
p_{P}=p_{Q}\equiv p .
\]

For non‑relativistic speeds the momentum is \(p_{i}=M_{i}v_{i}\). Hence

\[
M_{P}v_{P}=M_{Q}v_{Q}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\frac{v_{P}}{v_{Q}}=\frac{M_{Q}}{M_{P}} .
\]

This is exactly statement (C). (If one kept the full relativistic expression \(p = \gamma m v\) the ratio would include \(\gamma\) factors, but for the typical fission fragment speeds (\(\sim 0.03c\)) the non‑relativistic approximation is adequate.)

---

### Why (D) is correct

With equal momenta,
\[
E_{P}=\frac{p^{2}}{2M_{P}},\qquad
E_{Q}=\frac{p^{2}}{2M_{Q}}.
\]

Adding gives

\[
E_{P}+E_{Q}=\frac{p^{2}}{2}\!\left(\frac{1}{M_{P}}+\frac{1}{M_{Q}}\right)
            =\frac{p^{2}}{2}\,\frac{M_{P}+M_{Q}}{M_{P}M_{Q}}
            =\frac{p^{2}}{2\mu},
\]

where \(\displaystyle \mu=\frac{M_{P}M_{Q}}{M_{P}+M_{Q}}\) is the reduced mass.  Inserting the result of (A), \(E_{P}+E_{Q}=\delta\,c^{2}\), yields

\[
p^{2}=2\mu\,\delta\,c^{2}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
p=c\,\sqrt{2\mu\,\delta}.
\]

Thus the momentum magnitude of each fragment is indeed  
\(p=c\sqrt{2\,\mu\,\delta}\), as stated in (D).

---

### Why (B) is incorrect

With \(p_P=p_Q=p\) one finds

\[
E_{P}=\frac{p^{2}}{2M_{P}}=\frac{M_{Q}}{M_{P}+M_{Q}}\,(E_{P}+E_{Q})
      =\frac{M_{Q}}{M_{P}+M_{Q}}\;\delta c^{2},
\]

and likewise \(E_{Q}=\frac{M_{P}}{M_{P}+M_{Q}}\;\delta c^{2}\).

Statement (B) gives the factor \(\frac{M_{P}}{M_{P}+M_{Q}}\) instead of \(\frac{M_{Q}}{M_{P}+M_{Q}}\).  Therefore (B) is wrong.

---

**Correct statements: (A), (C), (D).**

Let  $S$  be a square of side length  $1$ .  Two points are chosen independently at random on the sides of  $S$ .  The probability that the straight-line distance between the points is at least  $\tfrac12$  is  $\tfrac{a-b\pi}c$ , where  $a$ ,  $b$ , and  $c$  are positive integers and  $\gcd(a,b,c)=1$ .  What is  $a+b+c$ ? $\textbf{(A) }59\qquad\textbf{(B) }60\qquad\textbf{(C) }61\qquad\textbf{(D) }62\qquad\textbf{(E) }63$

Let the perimeter of the unit square be parametrised by a distance \(s\in[0,4)\);  
\(0\le s<1\) gives the bottom side, \(1\le s<2\) the right side, etc.

For a point \(P(s)\) on the perimeter denote by \(L(s)\) the length of the part of
the perimeter that lies within Euclidean distance \(<\tfrac12\) from \(P(s)\).
The probability that a second uniformly chosen point lies within that distance is  

\[
\frac{L(s)}{4},
\]

so the desired probability for the ordered pair of points is the average of
\(L(s)/4\) over \(s\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1.  When the two points are on the **same side**

Let \(P\) be on the bottom side at abscissa \(x\in[0,1]\).

The points on the same side that are less than \(\tfrac12\) away are those with
\(|x-x'|<\tfrac12\).
Hence for that side the length of admissible points is

\[
L_{\text{same}}(x)=
\begin{cases}
x+\tfrac12 , & 0\le x\le\tfrac12 , \\
\tfrac32 -x , & \tfrac12\le x\le1 .
\end{cases}
\]

Its integral is  

\[
\int_{0}^{1} L_{\text{same}}(x)\,dx=\frac34 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.  When the points are on **adjacent sides**

Suppose again \(P=(x,0)\) is on the bottom side, \(0\le x\le \tfrac12\).
The points on the left side that are within distance \(\tfrac12\) satisfy
\(x^2+y^2<\tfrac14\); hence

\[
L_{\text{left}}(x)=\sqrt{\tfrac14-x^2},\qquad 0\le x\le\tfrac12 .
\]

For \(\tfrac12\le x\le1\) the admissible points lie on the right side,
with length  

\[
L_{\text{right}}(x)=\sqrt{\tfrac14-(1-x)^2}.
\]

Thus

\[
\int_{0}^{1}L_{\text{adj}}(x)\,dx
=2\int_{0}^{1/2}\sqrt{\tfrac14-x^2}\,dx
=\frac{\pi}{8},
\]

because \(\int_{0}^{r}\!\!\sqrt{r^{\,2}-x^{\,2}}\,dx=\dfrac{\pi r^{\,2}}{4}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.  Average length \(L(s)\)

For a point on a given side

\[
\int_{0}^{1}\!\bigl(L_{\text{same}}(x)+L_{\text{adj}}(x)\bigr)dx
= \frac34+\frac{\pi}{8}\;.
\]

Hence the mean length of the perimeter portion that lies inside the unit
circle of radius \(\tfrac12\) is

\[
\overline{L}= \frac34+\frac{\pi}{8}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.  Probability that the distance is **less** than \(\tfrac12\)

For a random first point we have

\[
P(\text{dist}<\tfrac12)=\frac{\overline{L}}{4}
=\frac{3}{16}+\frac{\pi}{32}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 5.  Probability that the distance is **at least** \(\tfrac12\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
P(\text{dist}\ge\tfrac12)
&=1-\left(\frac{3}{16}+\frac{\pi}{32}\right)  \\
&=\frac{13}{16}-\frac{\pi}{32}\\[2pt]
&=\frac{26-\pi}{32}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus the probability has the form \(\dfrac{a-b\pi}{c}\) with  
\(a=26,\;b=1,\;c=32\) and \(\gcd(a,b,c)=1\).

Finally,

\[
a+b+c=26+1+32=59 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{59}
\]

A uniform plank of length L = 6.0 m and mass M = 90 kg rests on sawhorses separated by D = 1.5 m and equidistant from the center of the plank. Cousin Throckmorton wants to stand on the right-hand end of the plank. If the plank is to remain at rest, how massive can Throckmorton be? (Unit: kg)

The right‑hand support will keep the whole weight of the system as the left support begins to lose contact.  
From static equilibrium

\[
R_{\text{left}}+R_{\text{right}}=Mg+m_c g ,
\]

\[
R_{\text{right}}\,(D)-Mg\left(\frac{D}{2}\right)-m_c g \left(\frac{3D}{2}\right)=0 .
\]

Solving for \(R_{\text{left}}\) and setting it to zero gives

\[
m_c=\frac{M}{3}.
\]

With \(M=90\,\text{kg}\),

\[
m_c_{\max}=\frac{90\;\text{kg}}{3}=30\;\text{kg}.
\]

\[
\boxed{30\;\text{kg}}
\]
For how many ordered pairs of positive integers $(x,y),$ with $y<x\le 100,$ are both $\frac xy$ and $\frac{x+1}{y+1}$ integers?

Call a positive integer $n$ $k$ - pretty if $n$ has exactly $k$ positive divisors and $n$ is divisible by $k$ . For example, $18$ is $6$ -pretty. Let $S$ be the sum of the positive integers less than $2019$ that are $20$ -pretty. Find $\tfrac{S}{20}$ .

For a positive integer \(n\) let \(d(n)\) be the number of its positive divisors.  
We need all \(n<2019\) such that  

\[
d(n)=20 \qquad\text{and}\qquad 20\mid n .
\]

---

### 1.  Factorisations that give \(d(n)=20\)

If \(n=p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdots p_{k}^{a_{k}}\) then  

\[
d(n)=(a_{1}+1)(a_{2}+1)\cdots(a_{k}+1)=20.
\]

Factorising 20 into factors \(\ge 2\) gives the following possibilities for the
exponents:

| pattern of \((a_i+1)\) | exponents \((a_i)\) | shape of \(n\) |
|------------------------|---------------------|----------------|
| 20 | 19 | \(p^{19}\) |
| 10·2 | 9,1 | \(p^{9}q\) |
| 5·4 | 4,3 | \(p^{4}q^{3}\) |
| 2·2·5 | 1,1,4 | \(p^{4}q r\) |

Hence every \(20\)-pretty integer has one of the shapes above.

---

### 2.  Add the divisibility requirement

Because \(20=2^{2}\cdot 5\), every such integer must contain the factor \(20\).

* **Pattern \(p^{19}\)**  
  \(2^{19}\!>\!2019\); no number of this shape fits.

* **Pattern \(p^{9}q\)**  
  The only way to contain \(20\) is to have \(2^{9}\cdot5\) (or \(5^{9}\cdot2\)), both of which exceed 2019.  
  No number of this shape works.

* **Pattern \(p^{4}q^{3}\)**  
  The prime that carries exponent 4 must be 2 (otherwise we could not get \(2^{2}\)).  
  Then \(q\) must be 5; otherwise 5 would be missing.  
  Thus \(n=2^{4}\cdot5^{3}=2000<2019\).  
  This gives one admissible number.

* **Pattern \(p^{4}qr\)**  
  To get the factor \(2^{2}\) we require \(p=2\).  
  Since we also need a factor 5, we set \(q=5\).  
  The remaining prime \(r\) can be any prime distinct from 2 and 5.  
  Thus

  \[
  n = 2^{4}\cdot5\cdot r = 80r,
  \]
  with \(r\) a prime and \(n<2019\).

  The inequality \(80r<2019\) gives \(r<25\).  
  Prime candidates: \(3,7,11,13,17,19,23\).

  The corresponding numbers are

  \[
  240,\;560,\;880,\;1040,\;1360,\;1520,\;1840 .
  \]

All of these have \(d(n)=20\) and are divisible by 20.

---

### 3.  Sum of all admissible numbers

\[
\begin{aligned}
S &=2000 \;+\; (240+560+880+1040+1360+1520+1840) \\
  &=2000\;+\;7440 \\
  &=9440 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Finally,

\[
\frac{S}{20}=\frac{9440}{20}=472.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{472}
\]

We define a sequence of natural numbers by the initial values  $a_0 = a_1 = a_2 = 1$  and the recursion   $$  a_n = \bigg \lfloor \frac{n}{a_{n-1}a_{n-2}a_{n-3}} \bigg \rfloor  $$   
for all  $n \ge 3$ . Find the value of  $a_{2022}$ .
The Chi-square statistic $\chi^2=\sum_c\frac{(P(x)-Q(x))^2}{Q(x)}$ is (twice) the first term in the Taylor series expansion of $D(P||Q)$ about $Q$. True or False?

**True.**

The Kullback–Leibler divergence

\[
D(P\|Q)=\sum_{c}P(c)\log\frac{P(c)}{Q(c)}
\]

has a Taylor expansion around the point \(P=Q\) (i.e. for small deviations \(\delta_c=P(c)-Q(c)\)).  
Let

\[
P(c)=Q(c)+\delta_c,\qquad\sum_c\delta_c=0 .
\]

Then

\[
\begin{aligned}
D(P\|Q)
&=\sum_c (Q_c+\delta_c)\log\!\left(1+\frac{\delta_c}{Q_c}\right)   \\
&=\sum_c (Q_c+\delta_c)\Bigl(\frac{\delta_c}{Q_c}-\frac12\frac{\delta_c^2}{Q_c^2}+O(\delta^3)\Bigr) \\
&=\underbrace{\sum_c\delta_c}_{=0}
  +\frac12\sum_c\frac{\delta_c^2}{Q_c}+O(\delta^3).
\end{aligned}
\]

The first non‑zero term is therefore

\[
\frac12\sum_c\frac{(P(c)-Q(c))^2}{Q(c)}=\frac12\,\chi^2(P,Q).
\]

Hence, for \(P\) close to \(Q\),

\[
D(P\|Q)\approx\frac12\,\chi^2(P,Q),
\]

so the chi‑square statistic equals twice that first (non‑zero) term in the Taylor expansion. Thus the statement is **true**.

A circle with center $O$ has radius 25. Chord $\overline{AB}$ of length 30 and chord $\overline{CD}$ of length 14 intersect at point $P$ . The distance between the midpoints of the two chords is 12. The quantity $OP^2$ can be represented as $\frac{m}{n}$ , where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find the remainder when $m + n$ is divided by 1000.

For a chord of a circle, the perpendicular distance from the centre to the chord is

\[
d=\sqrt{R^{2}-\left(\frac{\ell}{2}\right)^{2}}
\]

where \(R\) is the radius and \(\ell\) is the length of the chord.

---

### 1.  Distances from \(O\) to the chords

\[
\begin{aligned}
d_1 &= \sqrt{25^2-\Bigl(\frac{30}{2}\Bigr)^2}= \sqrt{625-225}=20,\\[2pt]
d_2 &= \sqrt{25^2-\Bigl(\frac{14}{2}\Bigr)^2}= \sqrt{625-49}=24 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Let \(M_1\) and \(M_2\) be the midpoints of the chords.  
They lie on two circles of radii \(20\) and \(24\) centered at \(O\), and

\[
|M_{1}M_{2}|=12 .
\]

---

### 2.  The angle between the normals of the chord lines

Let \(\mathbf n_1\) and \(\mathbf n_2\) be unit normals to the chords.
Their dot product is

\[
\mathbf n_1\!\cdot\!\mathbf n_2
   =\frac{|M_1|^2+|M_2|^2-|M_1M_2|^2}
           {2|M_1||M_2|}
   =\frac{20^2+24^2-12^2}{2\cdot20\cdot24}
   =\frac{832}{960}
   =\frac{13}{15}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\cos\theta=\frac{13}{15},
\qquad 
\theta=\angle(\mathbf n_1,\mathbf n_2).
\]

---

### 3.  Intersection point \(P\)

The equations of the lines are

\[
\mathbf n_{1}\!\cdot\!\mathbf r =20,\qquad  
\mathbf n_{2}\!\cdot\!\mathbf r =24 .
\]

Solving the linear system gives

\[
\mathbf r =\frac{1}{1-\cos^{2}\theta}\,
          \bigl[\,20\,\mathbf n_1-24\,\mathbf n_2
          -2\,\cos\theta\,(\;20\,\mathbf n_2-24\,\mathbf n_1)\bigr].
\]

The squared distance from the centre is

\[
OP^{2}
   =\frac{20^{2}+24^{2}-2\cdot20\cdot24\,\cos\theta}
          {1-\cos^{2}\theta } .
\]

Insert \(\cos\theta = \dfrac{13}{15}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
OP^{2}
  &=\frac{400+576-2\cdot20\cdot24\left(\frac{13}{15}\right)}
          {1-\left(\frac{13}{15}\right)^{2}}  \\[3pt]
  &=\frac{976-832}{\displaystyle 1-\frac{169}{225}}
   =\frac{144}{\frac{56}{225}}
   =\frac{144\cdot225}{56}
   =\frac{4050}{7}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The fraction \(\dfrac{4050}{7}\) is already in lowest terms.

Hence \(m=4050,\; n=7\) and

\[
m+n = 4050+7 = 4057.
\]

Finally,

\[
4057\;\text{mod}\;1000 \;=\; \boxed{57}.
\]

Let $ABCD$ be an isosceles trapezoid with $AD=BC$ and $AB<CD.$ Suppose that the distances from $A$ to the lines $BC,CD,$ and $BD$ are $15,18,$ and $10,$ respectively. Let $K$ be the area of $ABCD.$ Find $\sqrt2 \cdot K.$

Misha rolls a standard, fair six-sided die until she rolls 1-2-3 in that order on three consecutive rolls. The probability that she will roll the die an odd number of times is $\dfrac{m}{n}$ where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $m+n$ .

Let  

* \(S_0\) – no part of the pattern \(123\) has been matched  
* \(S_1\) – the last roll was a 1 (suffix \(1\))  
* \(S_2\) – the last two rolls were \(12\) (suffix \(12\))  
* \(S_3\) – pattern \(123\) has just appeared (absorbing state)

The die is fair, so every outcome has probability \(1/6\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Transition table

| from | roll | to |
|------|------|----|
| \(S_0\) | 1 | \(S_1\) |
| \(S_0\) | 2,3,4,5,6 | \(S_0\) |
| \(S_1\) | 2 | \(S_2\) |
| \(S_1\) | 1 | \(S_1\) |
| \(S_1\) | 3,4,5,6 | \(S_0\) |
| \(S_2\) | 3 | \(S_3\) **(absorb in 1 roll)** |
| \(S_2\) | 1 | \(S_1\) |
| \(S_2\) | 2,4,5,6 | \(S_0\) |

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Parity equations

Let  

* \(x_s=\Pr(\text{absorbing in an odd number of further rolls}\mid\text{state }s)\)  
* \(y_s=1-x_s\) (probability of eventual absorption in an even number of rolls).

From one roll, the parity of the remaining number of rolls is flipped.  
Hence

\[
\begin{aligned}
x_0&=\frac16\,y_1+\frac56\,y_0, \\
x_1&=\frac16\,y_2+\frac16\,y_1+\frac46\,y_0,\\
x_2&=\frac16\cdot 1+\frac16\,y_1+\frac46\,y_0 ,
\end{aligned}
\]
(the term \(1\) in the last equation corresponds to finishing immediately after the roll that gives \(3\)).

Replace \(y_s\) by \(1-x_s\) :

\[
\begin{aligned}
x_0 &= 1-\frac16x_1-\frac56x_0   \tag{1}\\
x_1 &= 1-\frac1{6}(x_2+x_1+4x_0)  \tag{2}\\
x_2 &= 1-\frac1{6}(x_1+4x_0) .     \tag{3}
\end{aligned}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Solving

From (1) \(x_1=6-11x_0\).  
Insert this in (2) and (3):

\[
\begin{cases}
7x_1+x_2+4x_0=6,\\
6x_2+x_1+4x_0=6 .
\end{cases}
\]

Subtracting gives \(x_2=\frac{6}{5}x_1\).  
Using \(x_1=6-11x_0\) we obtain

\[
\frac{41}{5}(6-11x_0)+4x_0=6
       \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;x_0=\frac{216}{431}.
\]

Thus the probability that the total number of rolls is odd equals

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \frac{216}{431}} .
\]

Since \(431\) is prime and shares no common factor with \(216=2^3\cdot3^3\), the fraction is already in lowest terms.

Hence \(m=216,\; n=431\) and

\[
m+n=216+431=\boxed{647}.
\]
Find the number of sets $\{a,b,c\}$ of three distinct positive integers with the property that the product of $a,b,$ and $c$ is equal to the product of $11,21,31,41,51,$ and $61$ .

The product in question is  

\[
N = 11\cdot 21\cdot 31\cdot 41\cdot 51\cdot 61 .
\]

Factorising each factor:

\[
11=11,\quad 21=3\cdot 7,\quad 31=31,\quad 41=41,\quad 51=3\cdot 17,\quad 61=61 .
\]

Hence

\[
N = 3^2\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 17\cdot 31\cdot 41\cdot 61 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Counting all ordered triples \((a,b,c)\)

To obtain a factorisation \(a\,b\,c=N\) we have to distribute the prime
factors among the three ordered positions.

* For the six distinct primes \(7,11,17,31,41,61\) each can be put in any
  of the three positions – \(3^6\) possibilities.
* The prime \(3\) occurs twice.  The two identical 3‑s can be distributed
  among the three positions in  
  \(\displaystyle \binom{3+2-1}{2}=6\) ways.

Hence the number of ordered triples \((a,b,c)\) (with no restriction on
repetition) is  

\[
T = 3^6\cdot 6 = 4374 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Subtracting the triples in which two numbers are equal

If two of \(a,b,c\) are equal, say \(a=b=x\), then \(x^2y=N\).
Because \(x^2\) must divide \(N=3^2\bigl(7\cdot 11\cdot 17\cdot 31\cdot 41\cdot61\bigr)\),
the only possibilities for \(x\) are \(1\) or \(3\):

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
x & y=N/x^2\\ \hline
1 & N \\
3 & 7\cdot 11\cdot 17\cdot 31\cdot 41\cdot 61
\end{array}
\]

Thus there are two unordered solutions \(\{1,1,N\}\) and
\(\{3,3,M\}\) (\(M=N/9\)).
Each gives three ordered permutations, so

\[
E = 2\cdot 3 = 6
\]

ordered triples contain a repeated number.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Triples with all three numbers distinct  

\[
D_{\text{ordered}} = T - E = 4374 - 6 = 4368 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  From ordered to unordered triples

All numbers are distinct, so each unordered set \(\{a,b,c\}\) corresponds to
\(3!=6\) ordered triples.  Therefore

\[
D_{\text{unordered}}
  = \frac{D_{\text{ordered}}}{6}
  = \frac{4368}{6}
  = 728 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{728}
\]
Find the ratio of forward-bias to reverse-bias currents when the same voltage 1.5 V is applied in both forward and reverse. Assume room temperature 293 K.

**Answer**

Using the ideal diode equation  

\[
I = I_S\;\big[e^{\,qV/(kT)}-1\big]
\]

at room temperature \(T = 293\;{\rm K}\) we have  

\[
\frac{kT}{q}\;=\;\frac{1.380\,649\times10^{-23}\;{\rm J/K}\times 293\;{\rm K}}
                      {1.602\,176\!\times10^{-19}\;{\rm C}}
   \;\approx\; 0.0253\;{\rm V}.
\]

---

### 1.  Forward bias ( \(V=+1.5\;{\rm V}\) )

\[
I_F \;\approx\; I_S \; e^{\,1.5/(0.0253)}
          \;=\; I_S \;e^{59.3}
          \;\approx\; I_S \; \times 5.5\times10^{25}.
\]

(The “–1” term is negligible because \(e^{59.3}\gg 1\).)

---

### 2.  Reverse bias ( \(V=-1.5\;{\rm V}\) )

\[
I_R \;=\; I_S\;\big[e^{-1.5/(0.0253)}-1\big]
        \;\approx\; I_S\;\big[0 - 1\big]
        \;=\; -\,I_S .
\]

(The positive exponential term is \(e^{-59.3}\approx 10^{-26}\) and can be ignored.)

---

### 3.  Ratio of magnitudes

\[
\left|\frac{I_F}{I_R}\right|
   \;=\;\frac{I_S e^{59.3}}{I_S}
   \;=\; e^{59.3}
   \;\approx\; 5.5 \times 10^{25}.
\]

---

### Result

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \frac{|I_{\text{forward}}|}{|I_{\text{reverse}}|}\;\approx\;5\times10^{25}}
\]

So, when a 1.5‑V bias is applied in the forward direction the diode current is roughly \(10^{25}\) times larger in magnitude than the reverse‑bias current (which is essentially the saturation current). This enormous ratio illustrates the strong rectifying behavior of a diode at this bias.

Let $A$ be a $2n \times 2n$ matrix, with entries chosen independently at random. Every entry is chosen to be 0 or 1, each with probability $1/2$. Find the expected value of $\det(A-A^t)$ (as a function of $n$), where $A^t$ is the transpose of $A$.

Let  

\[
B=A-A^{T}\qquad(2n\times 2n).
\]

Then \(B\) is skew–symmetric, \(B^{T}=-B\) and \(b_{ii}=0\).
For \(i<j\)  

\[
b_{ij}=A_{ij}-A_{ji}\in\{-1,0,1\},
\]

with  

\[
\Pr(b_{ij}=1)=\Pr(b_{ij}=-1)=\tfrac14,\qquad   
\Pr(b_{ij}=0)=\tfrac12 .
\]

Thus \(b_{ij}\) and \(b_{kl}\) are independent when \(\{i,j\}\neq\{k,l\}\);  
in particular

\[
\mathbb E\,b_{ij}=0,\qquad 
\mathbb E\,b_{ij}^{2}=\tfrac12 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Determinant of a skew‑symmetric matrix

For an even‑dimensional skew‑symmetric matrix the determinant is the square
of its Pfaffian:

\[
\det B =\bigl(\operatorname{Pf}(B)\bigr)^{2}.
\]

For \(2n\times 2n\) matrices

\[
\operatorname{Pf}(B)=
\sum_{M} \varepsilon(M)\!\!\prod_{(i,j)\in M} b_{ij},
\]

the sum running over all perfect matchings \(M\) of \(\{1,\dots ,2n\}\)
(\((2n-1)!!=(2n)!/(2^n n!)\) matchings), and \(\varepsilon(M)=\pm1\)
depends only on the matching.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Take expectation

\[
\det B=
\sum_{M,N}\varepsilon(M)\varepsilon(N)
\prod_{(i,j)\in M}b_{ij}
\prod_{(k,l)\in N}b_{kl}.
\]

Because the \(b_{ij}\) are independent and have mean \(0\),
the expectation of a product is \(0\) unless every \(b_{ij}\) appears an
even number of times.  
Hence the only surviving terms are those with \(M=N\); for \(M\neq N\)
some entry appears exactly once and its mean \(0\) kills the term.

For \(M=N\),

\[
\mathbb E\Bigl[\prod_{(i,j)\in M} b_{ij}^{\,2}\Bigr]
=\prod_{(i,j)\in M}\mathbb E[b_{ij}^{2}]
=\Bigl(\tfrac12\Bigr)^{n}.
\]

Thus

\[
\mathbb E[\det B]
= \bigl(\text{number of matchings}\bigr)\Bigl(\tfrac12\Bigr)^{n}
= (2n-1)!!\; 2^{-n}
= \frac{(2n)!}{4^{\,n}\,n!}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Result

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbb E\bigl[\det(A-A^{T})\bigr]=
\frac{(2n-1)!!}{2^{\,n}}
=\frac{(2n)!}{4^{\,n}\,n!}}
\]

(The first few values are \(0.5,\,0.75,\,1.875,\dots\).)

There are two distinguishable flagpoles, and there are $19$ flags, of which $10$ are identical blue flags, and $9$ are identical green flags. Let $N$ be the number of distinguishable arrangements using all of the flags in which each flagpole has at least one flag and no two green flags on either pole are adjacent. Find the remainder when $N$ is divided by $1000$ .

For a pole that contains \(b\) blue flags and \(g\) green flags the green flags must be separated by at least one blue flag.  
Thus the green flags can be put into the \(b+1\) gaps that are created by the \(b\) blues:

\[
\text{arrangements on one pole}= \binom{b+1}{g}\qquad(0\le g\le b+1).
\]

---

### Generating function for one pole  
Let  

\[
F(u,v)=\sum_{b\ge 0}\sum_{g\ge 0}\binom{b+1}{g}u^{\,b}v^{\,g}.
\]

For fixed \(b\)

\[
\sum_{g=0}^{b+1}\binom{b+1}{g}v^g=(1+v)^{\,b+1},
\]

hence  

\[
F(u,v)=\sum_{b\ge 0}u^b(1+v)^{\,b+1}
      =(1+v)\sum_{b\ge 0}[u(1+v)]^b
      =\frac{1+v}{1-u(1+v)} .
\]

\(F(u,v)\) counts all arrangements for *one* pole (including the empty pole).

---

### Two poles  
Since the poles are distinguishable, the generating function for the two poles is \(F(u,v)^2\).  
The coefficient of \(u^{10}v^9\) gives the number of arrangements of all 19 flags, however it also counts the cases where one pole is empty.

First find that coefficient.

\[
F(u,v)^2=\frac{(1+v)^2}{[1-u(1+v)]^2}
        =(1+v)^2\sum_{k\ge0}(k+1)\bigl(u(1+v)\bigr)^k .
\]

The term with \(u^{10}\) comes from \(k=10\):

\[
(10+1)u^{10}(1+v)^{12}=11\,u^{10}\sum_{j=0}^{12}\binom{12}{j}v^j .
\]

The coefficient of \(v^9\) is \(11\binom{12}{9}=11\cdot220=2420\).

Thus  

\[
[\,u^{10}v^9\,]\,F(u,v)^2 = 2420 .
\]

---

### Subtract the empty–pole cases  
If all 10 blues and 9 greens are put on one pole, the number of arrangements on that pole is

\[
\binom{10+1}{9}=\binom{11}{9}=55,
\]

and the other pole is empty (1 arrangement).  
Each pole could be the empty one, so we subtract \(2\times55=110\).

\[
N = 2420-110 = 2310 .
\]

---

### Remainder modulo \(1000\)

\[
2310 \equiv 310 \pmod{1000}.
\]

\[
\boxed{310}
\]

You identified several new antigens in a refractory pancreatic solid tumor and want to target them with the chimeric antigen receptor T-cell therapy. You design your chimera so that the cytosolic side has a three-domain part with the activation domain at the C-terminus, and the monospecific scFv is at the extracellular side, following the transmembrane domain and a spacer. You pack the construct into the lentiviral vector and deliver them into the isolated CD8+ cells. After in vitro amplification and purification, you will infuse the cells into your experimental model organism and observe the reaction of the carcinoma. Which of the statements below is true?
Answer Choices:
(A) antibody part is at 3', and the signaling part is at 5' of the transforming vector
(B) your variable moiety recognizes multiple epitopes
(C) regulatory T cells are involved in tumor elimination
(D) tumor antigens are transported through the Golgi

**Answer: D. Tumor antigens are transported through the Golgi.**  

**Why this statement is true:**  
- Most cell‑surface tumor antigens (e.g., MUC1, HER2, mesothelin, etc.) are synthesized as membrane or secreted proteins that enter the secretory pathway.  
- These proteins are co‑translationally inserted into the endoplasmic reticulum, glycosylated, and then trafficked through the Golgi apparatus before finally being delivered to the plasma membrane.  
- Because the CAR T‑cells recognize these surface antigens, the antigens must have passed through the Golgi to reach the cell surface.

The other choices are incorrect:  
- **(A)** The antibody (scFv) domain is at the N‑terminus (5′) of the CAR coding sequence, with the cytoplasmic signaling domain at the C‑terminus (3′).  
- **(B)** A monospecific scFv recognises a single epitope, not multiple ones.  
- **(C)** Regulatory T cells generally suppress antitumor responses rather than mediate tumor elimination.
Find the sum of all positive integers $a=2^n3^m$ where $n$ and $m$ are non-negative integers, for which $a^6$ is not a divisor of $6^a$ .

For a prime factor \(p\), the exponent of \(p\) in \(a^6\) must not exceed the exponent of \(p\) in \(6^a\) for \(a^6\mid 6^a\).

Let  
\[
a=2^n3^m \qquad (n,m\ge0).
\]

Then  

\[
a^6=2^{6n}3^{6m},\qquad   
6^{a}=(2^{a})(3^{a}).
\]

For \(a^6\mid6^a\) we need  
\[
6n\le a\quad\text{and}\quad 6m\le a. \tag{1}
\]

Hence \(a^6\nmid6^a\) iff  

\[
a<6n \ \text{or}\ a<6m. \tag{2}
\]

---

### 1.  Cases with \(n=0\)

Here \(a=3^m\).

- If \(m=1\): \(a=3<6m=6\).  (fails)
- If \(m=2\): \(a=9<6m=12\). (fails)
- For \(m\ge3\): \(3^m\ge 27\ge 6m\), so condition (2) fails.  

Thus the admissible \(a\) are \(a=3,9\).

---

### 2.  Cases with \(m=0\)

Now \(a=2^n\).

- \(n=1\): \(a=2<6n=6\). (fails)
- \(n=2\): \(a=4<12\). (fails)
- \(n=3\): \(a=8<18\). (fails)
- \(n=4\): \(a=16<24\). (fails)
- For \(n\ge5\): \(2^n\ge32\ge 6n\), so condition (2) fails.

Thus the admissible \(a\) are \(a=2,4,8,16\).

---

### 3.  Cases with \(n\ge1,\;m\ge1\)

For \(n,m\ge1\),

\[
a=2^n3^m \ge 3\cdot2^n \ge 6n,\qquad
a=2^n3^m\ge 2\cdot3^m \ge 6m,
\]

so (2) never holds. Hence no further \(a\) are counted.

---

### Sum of all admissible \(a\)

\[
a\in\{2,4,8,16,3,9\}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\text{sum}=2+4+8+16+3+9=42.
\]

\[
\boxed{42}
\]

Given that $O$ is a regular octahedron, that $C$ is the cube whose vertices are the centers of the faces of $O,$ and that the ratio of the volume of $O$ to that of $C$ is $\frac mn,$ where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime integers, find $m+n.$

Let the regular octahedron \(O\) have vertices  

\[
( \pm a,0,0),\quad (0,\pm a,0),\quad (0,0,\pm a)
\]

centered at the origin.  
Its edge length is \(s=\sqrt{(a-0)^2+(0-a)^2}=a\sqrt{2}\).

---

### Volume of the octahedron  
For a regular octahedron of side length \(s\),

\[
V_O =\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}\,s^3 .
\]

With \(s=a\sqrt{2}\),

\[
V_O=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}\,(a\sqrt{2})^{\,3}
       =\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}\,2\sqrt{2}\,a^{3}
       =\frac{4}{3}a^{3}.
\]

---

### Vertices of the cube \(C\)

Take a face of \(O\) given by \(x+y+z=a\) (first octant).  
Its three vertices are \((a,0,0),\,(0,a,0),\,(0,0,a)\).
The centre (centroid) of this triangular face is

\[
\left(\frac{a}{3},\frac{a}{3},\frac{a}{3}\right).
\]

Doing this for each of the \(8\) faces gives the cube vertices

\[
(\pm a/3,\; \pm a/3,\; \pm a/3),
\]

so the cube side length is  

\[
L=\frac{2a}{3}.
\]

Hence  

\[
V_C=L^{3}=\left(\frac{2a}{3}\right)^{3}
        =\frac{8a^{3}}{27}.
\]

---

### Ratio of volumes

\[
\frac{V_O}{V_C}=
\frac{\dfrac{4}{3}a^{3}}
     {\dfrac{8}{27}a^{3}}
=\frac{4}{3}\cdot\frac{27}{8}
=\frac{108}{24}
=\frac{9}{2}.
\]

Thus  
\[
\frac{V_O}{V_C}=\frac{9}{2}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
m=9,\; n=2.
\]

The integers \(m\) and \(n\) are relatively prime, so

\[
m+n = 9+2 = 11.
\]

\[
\boxed{11}
\]

Equilateral $\triangle ABC$ is inscribed in a circle of radius 2. Extend $\overline{AB}$ through $B$ to point $D$ so that $AD=13,$ and extend $\overline{AC}$ through $C$ to point $E$ so that $AE = 11.$ Through $D,$ draw a line $l_1$ parallel to $\overline{AE},$ and through $E,$ draw a line $l_2$ parallel to $\overline{AD}.$ Let $F$ be the intersection of $l_1$ and $l_2.$ Let $G$ be the point on the circle that is collinear with $A$ and $F$ and distinct from $A.$ Given that the area of $\triangle CBG$ can be expressed in the form $\frac{p\sqrt{q}}{r},$ where $p, q,$ and $r$ are positive integers, $p$ and $r$ are relatively prime, and $q$ is not divisible by the square of any prime, find $p+q+r.$

The coordinates of the vertices of the equilateral triangle can be taken as  

\[
A(2,0),\qquad B(-1,\sqrt3),\qquad C(-1,-\sqrt3),
\]

since the circle has radius \(2\).

---

### Points \(D\) and \(E\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
AD=13 &: 
  D=A+\frac{13}{AB}(B-A)
   =\bigl(2-\frac{13\sqrt3}{2},\, \frac{13}{2}\bigr)      \\
AE=11 &: 
  E=A+\frac{11}{AC}(C-A)
   =\bigl(2-\frac{11\sqrt3}{2},\, -\frac{11}{2}\bigr).
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### Lines \(l_1,l_2\) and their intersection \(F\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
l_1 &: y-\frac{13}{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt3}\bigl(x-\frac{4-13\sqrt3}{2}\bigr),\\
l_2 &: y+\frac{11}{2}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt3}\bigl(x-\frac{4-11\sqrt3}{2}\bigr).
\end{aligned}
\]

Solving gives  

\[
F=(\,2-12\sqrt3,\;1\,).
\]

---

### Point \(G\)

\(G\) is the second intersection of the circle \(x^2+y^2=4\) with the line through \(A\) and \(F\).

The equation of line \(AF\) is \(x+12\sqrt3\,y=2\).  
Substituting in \(x^2+y^2=4\):

\[
(2-12\sqrt3 y)^2+y^2=4\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
y=\frac{48\sqrt3}{433}\ \text{or}\ y=0.
\]

The solution \(y=0\) gives \(A\).  
Thus  

\[
G\!:\;
\begin{cases}
y_G =\dfrac{48\sqrt3}{433},\\[4pt]
x_G = 2-12\sqrt3\,y_G =
      2-\dfrac{1728}{433}=-\dfrac{862}{433}.
\end{cases}
\]

---

### Area of \(\triangle CBG\)

The side \(BC\) is vertical, with length  

\[
BC =|\,\sqrt3-(-\sqrt3)\,| =2\sqrt3.
\]

The perpendicular distance from \(G\) to line \(BC\) (the horizontal distance) is  

\[
|x_G-(-1)|=\Bigl|-\frac{862}{433}+1\Bigr|
          =\frac{429}{433}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\text{Area}_{CBG}
=\frac12(BC)\times\text{height}
   =\frac12\,(2\sqrt3)\left(\frac{429}{433}\right)
   =\frac{429\sqrt3}{433}.
\]

This is already in lowest terms: \(p=429,\ q=3,\ r=433\).

\[
p+q+r = 429+3+433 = \boxed{865}.
\]
What is the smallest number of standard deviations from the mean that we must go if we want to ensure that we have at least 50% of the data of a distribution?

**Answer – in general (any distribution)**  
The weakest guarantee that can be made, independent of the shape of the distribution, is given by **Chebyshev’s inequality**.  

Chebyshev says  

\[
P(|X-\mu| < k\sigma) \;\ge\; 1 - \frac{1}{k^2}.
\]

To guarantee at least 50 % of the observations fall inside that interval we set

\[
1 - \frac{1}{k^2} \;\ge\; 0.5
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\frac{1}{k^2}\;\le\;0.5
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
k^2 \;\ge\; 2
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
k \;\ge\; \sqrt{2}\;\approx\;1.414.
\]

So **at least \(\sqrt{2}\) standard deviations** from the mean must be used to be sure that half of the data lie within that radius, for any possible distribution.

---

**If the distribution is known to be normal**  
For a normal distribution the requirement is much tighter.  
We need the *symmetric* interval \([\mu - k\sigma, \mu + k\sigma]\) to contain 50 % of the probability:

\[
2\Phi(k)-1 = 0.5
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\Phi(k) = 0.75
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
k \approx 0.6745.
\]

So for a normal distribution a distance of about **0.6745 σ** from the mean (on either side) is enough to capture half of the data.

In the most general setting (any distribution), the guarantee is √2 σ.

A cube with side length 10 is suspended above a plane. The vertex closest to the plane is labeled $A$. The three vertices adjacent to vertex $A$ are at heights 10, 11, and 12 above the plane. The distance from vertex $A$ to the plane can be expressed as $ \frac{r-\sqrt{s}}{t}$, where $r$, $s$, and $t$ are positive integers, and $r+s+t<{1000}$. Find $r+s+t.$

Let the plane be the \(z\)-plane and let the vertex \(A\) have coordinates \((0,0,d)\) where \(d\) is its distance from the plane.

The cube has side length \(10\).  
Let the three edges from \(A\) be the vectors \(\mathbf u,\mathbf v,\mathbf w\).
Their vertical components are the differences between the heights of the adjacent vertices and \(d\):

\[
u_z = 10-d,\qquad v_z = 11-d,\qquad w_z = 12-d .
\]

Since \(\|\mathbf u\|=\|\mathbf v\|=\|\mathbf w\|=10\),

\[
(10-d)^2+(11-d)^2+(12-d)^2 = 10^2=100 .
\]

Expanding,

\[
3d^{2}-66d+265=0 .
\]

Solving,

\[
d=\frac{66\pm\sqrt{66^{2}-4\cdot3\cdot265}}{6}
=\frac{66\pm14\sqrt 6}{6}
=\frac{33\pm7\sqrt6}{3}.
\]

The vertex \(A\) is the closest to the plane, so \(d<10\).  
Thus

\[
d=\frac{33-7\sqrt6}{3}=\frac{33-\sqrt{294}}{3}.
\]

Hence the distance from \(A\) to the plane can be written as

\[
\frac{r-\sqrt{s}}{t}\quad\text{with}\quad
r=33,\; s=294,\; t=3 .
\]

Finally,

\[
r+s+t = 33+294+3 = 330.
\]

\[
\boxed{330}
\]
Find the number of positive integers less than $1000$ that can be expressed as the difference of two integral powers of $2.$

Let  

\[
n=2^{a}-2^{b}\qquad(a>b\ge 0,\;a,b\in\mathbb Z)
\]

be a positive integer less than \(1000\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Shape of the numbers

Write \(a=b+k\;(k\ge 1)\).  
Then

\[
n=2^{b}\bigl(2^{k}-1\bigr).
\]

Thus \(n\) equals a power of \(2\) times an odd number of the form
\(2^{k}-1\) (a Mersenne number).  
Conversely, every number of this form is the difference of two
powers of \(2\):  
\(2^{b}\bigl(2^{k}-1\bigr)=2^{b+k}-2^{b}\).

Hence the required numbers are exactly

\[
\{\,2^{b}(2^{k}-1)\mid k\ge 1,\;b\ge 0,\;
2^{b}(2^{k}-1)<1000\,\}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Counting the possibilities

For fixed \(k\), set \(M_k=2^{k}-1\) (an odd number).  
The condition \(2^{b}M_k<1000\) gives

\[
b\le \Bigl\lfloor \log_{2}\!\Bigl(\frac{999}{M_k}\Bigr)\Bigr\rfloor .
\]

Compute \(M_k\) while \(M_k<1000\):

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c}
k & M_k=2^k-1 &\bigl\lfloor\log_{2}(999/M_k)\bigr\rfloor &\text{no. of }b\\ \hline
1 & 1 & 9 & 10\\
2 & 3 & 8 & 9\\
3 & 7 & 7 & 8\\
4 & 15& 6 & 7\\
5 & 31& 5 & 6\\
6 & 63& 3 & 4\\
7 & 127&2 & 3\\
8 & 255&1 & 2\\
9 & 511&0 & 1\\
10&1023>1000 & & 0
\end{array}
\]

Adding the numbers of admissible \(b\)'s gives

\[
10+9+8+7+6+4+3+2+1 = 50 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Uniqueness of representation

If two pairs \((a,b)\) and \((c,d)\) gave the same number,

\[
2^{b}(2^{a-b}-1)=2^{d}(2^{c-d}-1),
\]

then, after factoring out the smaller power of \(2\), the left‑hand side is odd
while the right‑hand side is a power of \(2\) times an odd number.  
Thus the power of \(2\) must be the same on both sides and the odd parts the
same; consequently \((a,b)=(c,d)\).
Hence every pair produces a distinct integer, so the count obtained
in Section 2 is the required number of positive integers.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{50}
\]

Let $\mathcal{T}$ be the set of ordered triples $(x,y,z)$ of nonnegative real numbers that lie in the plane $x+y+z=1.$ Let us say that $(x,y,z)$ supports $(a,b,c)$ when exactly two of the following are true: $x\ge a, y\ge b, z\ge c.$ Let $\mathcal{S}$ consist of those triples in $\mathcal{T}$ that support $\left(\frac 12,\frac 13,\frac 16\right).$ The area of $\mathcal{S}$ divided by the area of $\mathcal{T}$ is $m/n,$ where $m_{}$ and $n_{}$ are relatively prime positive integers, find $m+n.$

The set \(\mathcal{T}\) is the standard 2‑simplex  
\[
\{(x,y,z)\mid x+y+z=1,\;x,y,z\ge 0\}
\]
whose area (in the plane \(x+y+z=1\)) is \(\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}\) or, after projecting to the \((x,y)\)-plane, \(\tfrac12\).

For the triple \((a,b,c)=\left(\tfrac12,\tfrac13,\tfrac16\right)\) the inequalities are

\[
x\ge \tfrac12,\qquad y\ge\tfrac13,\qquad z\ge\tfrac16.
\]

"Supports" means that **exactly two** of these inequalities are true.

The only point where all three hold is \((\tfrac12,\tfrac13,\tfrac16)\), which has no area.

Hence the set \(\mathcal{S}\) is the union of the following three disjoint triangles:

1. \(x\ge\tfrac12,\;y\ge\tfrac13,\;z<\tfrac16\)
   \[
   \text{vertices}\;( \tfrac12,\tfrac13 ),\ (\tfrac12,\tfrac12),\ (\tfrac23,\tfrac13) 
   \]
   Area \(=\frac12\!\left(\tfrac16\right)^2=\frac{1}{72}\).

2. \(x\ge\tfrac12,\;y<\tfrac13,\;z\ge\tfrac16\)
   \[
   \text{vertices}\;( \tfrac12,0 ),\ ( \tfrac56,0 ),\ (\tfrac12,\tfrac13) 
   \]
   Area \(=\frac12\!\left(\tfrac13\right)^2=\frac{1}{18}\).

3. \(x<\tfrac12,\;y\ge\tfrac13,\;z\ge\tfrac16\)
   \[
   \text{vertices}\;( 0,\tfrac13 ),\ ( 0,\tfrac56 ),\ (\tfrac12,\tfrac13) 
   \]
   Area \(=\frac12\!\left(\tfrac12\right)^2=\frac{1}{8}\).

Adding them,
\[
\text{Area}(\mathcal{S})=\frac{1}{72}+\frac{1}{18}+\frac{1}{8}
   =\frac{14}{72}=\frac{7}{36}.
\]

The area of \(\mathcal{T}\), projected onto the \((x,y)\)-plane, is \(\frac12\).  
Thus
\[
\frac{\text{Area}(\mathcal{S})}{\text{Area}(\mathcal{T})}
=\frac{7/36}{1/2}
=\frac{7}{18}.
\]

Hence \(m=7,\;n=18\) and \(m+n=25\).

\[
\boxed{25}
\]

For each positive integer $n,$ let $f(n) = \sum_{k = 1}^{100} \lfloor \log_{10} (kn) \rfloor$ . Find the largest value of $n$ for which $f(n) \le 300$ . Note: $\lfloor x \rfloor$ is the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$ .

Let  

\[
f(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{100}\bigl\lfloor\log_{10}(kn)\bigr\rfloor ,
\]

and observe that for any positive integer \(x\),

\[
\lfloor\log_{10}x\rfloor +1=\text{the number of decimal digits of }x.
\]

Denote by \(D(x)\) this number of digits.  
Then \(\lfloor\log_{10}x\rfloor=D(x)-1\) and

\[
f(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{100}\bigl(D(kn)-1\bigr)
     =\Bigl(\sum_{k=1}^{100}D(kn)\Bigr)-100 .
\]

Thus the restriction \(f(n)\le 300\) is equivalent to  

\[
\sum_{k=1}^{100}D(kn)\le 400. \tag{1}
\]

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1.  Monotonicity

For a fixed \(k\), \(kn\) is an increasing function of \(n\); therefore
\(D(kn)\) is a non‑decreasing function of \(n\).  
Hence the left–hand side of (1) is a non‑decreasing function of \(n\).
So once the inequality fails for some \(n\), it will fail for all larger
\(n\).

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.  Distribution of digit lengths for \(n\le 109\)

Let us determine, for a given \(n\), how many of the numbers \(kn\)
have \(3\)-, \(4\)-, \(5\)- etc. digits.

* \(3\) digits occur when \(kn<10^3=1000\).  
  Thus for \(k<1000/n\).

* \(4\) digits occur when \(10^3\le kn<10^4=10000\).  
  Thus for \(1000/n\le k<10000/n\).

* \(5\) digits occur when \(10^4\le kn<10^5=100000\).  
  Thus for \(10000/n\le k<100000/n\).

Since \(n\le 109\), the quantities \(1000/n\) and \(10000/n\) are
consecutive integers with at most one integer between them,
so only \(3\), \(4\), or \(5\) digit lengths can appear.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.  Explicit computation for \(n=109\)

For \(n=109\):

* For \(k=1,2,\dots ,9\): \(kn<1000\) → \(3\) digits ( \(9\) numbers).
* For \(k=10,\dots ,91\): \(1000\le kn<10000\) → \(4\) digits  
  ( \(91-10+1=82\) numbers).
* For \(k=92,\dots ,100\): \(10000\le kn<100000\) → \(5\) digits  
  ( \(9\) numbers).

The sum of digit lengths is  

\[
\sum_{k=1}^{100}D(kn)=9\cdot3+82\cdot4+9\cdot5=27+328+45=400 .
\]

Hence  

\[
f(109)=400-100=300\le 300 .
\]

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.  Checking \(n=110\)

For \(n=110\):

* \(k=1,\dots ,9\): \(3\) digits.
* \(k=10,\dots ,90\): \(4\) digits.
* \(k=91,\dots ,100\): \(5\) digits.

Thus  

\[
\sum_{k=1}^{100}D(kn)=9\cdot3+81\cdot4+10\cdot5=27+324+50=401,
\]
and consequently \(f(110)=301>300\).
Because the sum is non‑decreasing, every \(n>110\) will also give
\(f(n)>300\).

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Therefore, the largest positive integer \(n\) satisfying
\(f(n)\le 300\) is

\[
\boxed{109}.
\]

Let $\triangle ABC$ be a right triangle with right angle at $C.$ Let $D$ and $E$ be points on $\overline{AB}$ with $D$ between $A$ and $E$ such that $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{CE}$ trisect $\angle C.$ If $\frac{DE}{BE} = \frac{8}{15},$ then $\tan B$ can be written as $\frac{m \sqrt{p}}{n},$ where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers, and $p$ is a positive integer not divisible by the square of any prime. Find $m+n+p.$

Let  

\[
AC=a,\qquad BC=b,\qquad \angle B=\beta ,\qquad  t=\tan \beta=\frac{a}{b}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Finding the ratios \( \dfrac{AD}{AB}\) and \( \dfrac{BE}{AB}\)

In \(\triangle ACD\)

\[
\angle ACD=30^{\circ},\qquad 
\angle CAD=\angle CAB=90^{\circ}-\beta .
\]

Thus \(\angle CDA=180^{\circ}-\bigl(30^{\circ}+90^{\circ}-\beta\bigr)
        =60^{\circ}+\beta\).

Using the law of sines,

\[
\frac{AD}{\sin 30^{\circ}}=\frac{AC}{\sin(\angle CDA)}
      \Longrightarrow
\]
\[
AD=\frac{AC}{2}\cdot\frac{2AB}{\sqrt3\,BC+AC}
     =AB\;\frac{AC}{AC+\sqrt3\,BC}
     =AB\;\frac{a}{a+\sqrt3\,b}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle\frac{AD}{AB}=\frac{a}{a+\sqrt3\,b}}
\tag{1}
\]

In \(\triangle BCE\)

\[
\angle BCE=30^{\circ},\qquad 
\angle BEC=150^{\circ}-\beta .
\]

Again by the law of sines,

\[
\frac{BE}{\sin 30^{\circ}}
    =\frac{BC}{\sin(\angle BEC)}
    \Longrightarrow
BE=AB\;\frac{BC}{BC+\sqrt3\,AC}
    =AB\;\frac{b}{b+\sqrt3\,a}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle\frac{BE}{AB}=\frac{b}{b+\sqrt3\,a}}
\tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  The ratio \(\dfrac{DE}{BE}\)

Since \(AB=AD+DE+BE\),

\[
DE=AB-AD-BE
      =AB\!\left(1-\frac{AD}{AB}-\frac{BE}{AB}\right).
\]

Using (1) and (2),

\[
\frac{DE}{BE}
 =\frac{1-\dfrac{a}{a+\sqrt3b}-\dfrac{b}{b+\sqrt3a}}
          {\dfrac{b}{b+\sqrt3a}}
 =\frac{2a}{a+\sqrt3b}.
\]

With \(t=\dfrac{a}{b}\) this becomes

\[
\frac{DE}{BE}
   =\frac{2t}{t+\sqrt3}.                \tag{3}
\]

By hypothesis \(\displaystyle\frac{DE}{BE}=\frac{8}{15}\).  
Set (3) equal to \( \dfrac{8}{15}\):

\[
\frac{2t}{t+\sqrt3}=\frac{8}{15}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
30t=8t+8\sqrt3
\]

\[
22t=8\sqrt3
      \Longrightarrow 
t=\frac{8\sqrt3}{22}=\frac{4\sqrt3}{11}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Expressing \(\tan B\)

\[
\tan B=\frac{a}{b}=t=\frac{4\sqrt3}{11}.
\]

Here \(m=4,\; n=11\) (relatively prime) and \(p=3\) (square‑free).

\[
m+n+p=4+11+3=18 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{18}
\]

In $\triangle ABC, AB = AC = 10$ and $BC = 12$ . Point $D$ lies strictly between $A$ and $B$ on $\overline{AB}$ and point $E$ lies strictly between $A$ and $C$ on $\overline{AC}$ so that $AD = DE = EC$ . Then $AD$ can be expressed in the form $\dfrac{p}{q}$ , where $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $p+q$ .

Let  

\[
AD=DE=EC=x .
\]

Because \(EC=x\) we have  

\[
AE=AC-EC=10-x .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Find \(\cos \angle BAC\)

In \(\triangle ABC\),

\[
AB=AC=10,\qquad BC=12 .
\]

Using the Law of Cosines,

\[
\cos \angle BAC=
\frac{AB^{2}+AC^{2}-BC^{2}}{2\cdot AB\cdot AC}
=\frac{100+100-144}{200}
=\frac{56}{200}
=\frac{7}{25}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Apply the Law of Cosines in \(\triangle ADE\)

In \(\triangle ADE\)

* \(AD=x\)  
* \(DE=x\)  
* \(AE=10-x\)

The angle between \(AD\) and \(AE\) is the same as \(\angle BAC\).
Hence, by the Law of Cosines for the side \(DE\) (which is opposite
the angle at \(A\)),

\[
DE^{2}=AD^{2}+AE^{2}-2\,(AD)(AE)\cos\angle BAC .
\]

Substituting \(DE=AD=x\) and \(\cos\angle BAC=\tfrac{7}{25}\):

\[
x^{2}=x^{2}+(10-x)^{2}-2x(10-x)\cdot\frac{7}{25}.
\]

Cancel \(x^{2}\) and divide by \(10-x\;(>0)\):

\[
10-x=2x\cdot\frac{7}{25}.
\]

Thus

\[
x(1+2\cdot\tfrac{7}{25})=10
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
x=\frac{10}{1+\frac{14}{25}}
   =\frac{10}{\frac{39}{25}}
   =\frac{10\cdot25}{39}
   =\frac{250}{39}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Result

\[
AD=\frac{250}{39},
\qquad p=250,\quad q=39,\quad p+q=250+39=289 .
\]

\[
\boxed{289}
\]

Which one of the following is the least correct statement about the following post-transcription processes?


Answer Choices:
(A) Some histone mRNAs end in a stem loop structure instead of poly-A tail 
(B) In animals, the introns in the primary messenger RNA for canonical histones are removed within the nucleus
(C) A mature messenger RNA may carry different combinations of exons from the original primary transcript
(D) Sometimes, the portion of RNA transcribed from an intron can cut itself out of the primary messenger RNA without the need for a spliceosome
(D) – Some introns can self‑splice, but this mechanism is rare in animal nuclear pre‑mRNAs (most introns are removed by the spliceosome).

Club Truncator is in a soccer league with six other teams, each of which it plays once. In any of its 6 matches, the probabilities that Club Truncator will win, lose, or tie are each $\frac {1}{3}$ . The probability that Club Truncator will finish the season with more wins than losses is $\frac {m}{n}$ , where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $m + n$ .

For each of the 6 matches

\[
P(\text{win})=\frac13,\qquad 
P(\text{tie})=\frac13,\qquad 
P(\text{loss})=\frac13
\]

and the results of the matches are independent.

Let  
\(W=\) number of wins,  
\(L=\) number of losses,  
\(T=\) number of ties.  

We need \(P(W>L)\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Use symmetry

Define \(X\) as the difference in numbers of wins and losses

\[
X=W-L .
\]

Each match contributes \(+1\) (win), \(-1\) (loss), or \(0\) (tie), all with probability \(1/3\).
Because the distribution of each contribution is symmetric about \(0\), the distribution of
\(X\) is symmetric:
\[
P(X=d)=P(X=-d)\quad\text{for all }d.
\]

Hence

\[
P(X>0)=P(X<0)=\frac{1-P(X=0)}{2}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Compute \(P(X=0)\)

\(X=0\) means the number of wins equals the number of losses: \(W=L\).

Let \(W=L=w\).  
Then \(T=6-2w\).  
The possibilities for \(w\) are \(0,1,2,3\).

Number of sequences for each \(w\):

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
w & \text{count of sequences}= \displaystyle\frac{6!}{w!\,w!\,(6-2w)!}\\ \hline
0 & \frac{6!}{0!\,0!\,6!}=1\\
1 & \frac{6!}{1!\,1!\,4!}=30\\
2 & \frac{6!}{2!\,2!\,2!}=90\\
3 & \frac{6!}{3!\,3!\,0!}=20
\end{array}
\]

Total number of equally likely outcomes with \(W=L\) is  

\[
1+30+90+20=141 .
\]

Since all \(3^{6}=729\) outcomes are equally likely,

\[
P(X=0)=\frac{141}{729}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Find \(P(W>L)\)

\[
P(W>L)=P(X>0)=\frac{1-P(X=0)}{2}
          =\frac{1-\frac{141}{729}}{2}
          =\frac{\frac{588}{729}}{2}
          =\frac{588}{1458}
          =\frac{98}{243}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Final result

\[
\frac{m}{n}=\frac{98}{243}\quad\Rightarrow\quad m+n=98+243=341.
\]

\[
\boxed{341}
\]

For any $n \geq 1$, let $A$ denote the $\mathbb{C}$ algebra consisting of $n \times n$ upper triangular complex matrices $\left\{\left(\begin{array}{ccc}* & * & * \\ 0 & * & * \\ 0 & 0 & *\end{array}\right)_{n \times n}\right\}$. We shall consider the left $A$-modules (that is, $\mathbb{C}$-vector spaces $V$ with $\mathbb{C}$-algebra homomorphisms $\rho: A \rightarrow \operatorname{End}(V))$. (2) Determine all simple modules of $A$.

Let  

\[
A=\Bigl\{\begin{pmatrix}a_{11}&a_{12}&\dots & a_{1n}\\
0&a_{22}&\dots & a_{2n}\\
\vdots &  & \ddots &\vdots \\
0&0&\dots &a_{nn}\end{pmatrix}\Bigr\}\subseteq M_n(\mathbf C)
\]

and let a (left) $A$‑module be a $\mathbf C$–vector space $V$ equipped with an
algebra homomorphism $\rho :A\to \operatorname{End}(V)$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  The radical of \(A\)

The ideal of strictly upper–triangular matrices

\[
J:=\Bigl\{\begin{pmatrix}0&*&\dots&*\\
0&0&\dots&*\\
\vdots&&\ddots&\vdots\\
0&0&\dots&0\end{pmatrix}\Bigr\}
\]

is nilpotent (in fact \(J^{\,n}=0\)).  
It is precisely the Jacobson radical \(\operatorname{rad}A\).

Hence the quotient algebra

\[
A/J\;\cong\;\{ \text{diagonal matrices}\}\;\cong\;\mathbf C^n
\]

is semisimple.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Action of \(J\) on a simple module

Let \(S\) be a simple left \(A\)-module.  
Because \(J\) is nilpotent, \(J\) acts nilpotently on every finite–dimensional
module.  On a simple module this forces \(JS=0\).  
Thus the $A$‑action on \(S\) factors through the quotient \(A/J\):

\[
S\;\cong\; (A/J)\;\text{-module}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Simple modules of \(A/J\simeq \mathbf C^n\)

The algebra \(\mathbf C^n\) is a product of \(n\) copies of the field \(\mathbf C\);
hence it is semisimple with exactly \(n\) mutually non‑isomorphic simple modules,
each one–dimensional.  
Explicitly, for \(i=1,\dots ,n\) define

\[
\chi_i : A\longrightarrow \mathbf C,\qquad
\chi_i\!\left(\begin{pmatrix}a_{jk}\end{pmatrix}\right)=a_{ii}.
\]

\(\chi_i\) is a surjective algebra homomorphism with kernel the maximal left
ideal \(\ker\chi_i\).  
The corresponding one–dimensional \(A\)-module

\[
S_i=\mathbf C\quad \text{with}\quad a\cdot x =\chi_i(a)\,x
      \qquad (a\in A,\;\;x\in\mathbf C)
\]

is simple, and any simple \(A\)-module is isomorphic to one of the \(S_i\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Result

\[
\boxed{\text{The simple left $A$‑modules are exactly } 
S_1,\ldots ,S_n}
\]

where each \(S_i\) is one–dimensional and
\(a\in A\) acts by multiplication by the \((i,i)\)-entry of \(a\).

In particular there are \(n\) non‑isomorphic simple modules, each of dimension
\(1\); there are no simple \(A\)-modules of higher dimension.

The polynomial $f(z)=az^{2018}+bz^{2017}+cz^{2016}$ has real coefficients not exceeding $2019,$ and $f\left(\tfrac{1+\sqrt3i}{2}\right)=2015+2019\sqrt3i$ . Find the remainder when $f(1)$ is divided by $1000$ .

Let  

\[
w=\frac{1+\sqrt3\,i}{2}=e^{i\pi/3}\;,
\qquad\text{so }\; w^6=1,\; w^3=-1 .
\]

Because only the powers \(2018,\;2017,\;2016\) occur, we can use \(w^6=1\) to reduce them:

\[
2018\equiv 2\pmod 6,\qquad 
2017\equiv 1\pmod 6,\qquad 
2016\equiv 0\pmod 6 .
\]

Hence  

\[
f(w)=a\,w^{2}+b\,w+c .
\]

---

### 1.  Express \(w\) and \(w^2\)

\[
w   = \frac12+\frac{\sqrt3}{2} i, \qquad
w^2 = -\frac12+\frac{\sqrt3}{2} i .
\]

Thus  

\[
f(w)=a\!\left(-\frac12+\frac{\sqrt3}{2} i\right)
      +b\!\left(\frac12+\frac{\sqrt3}{2} i\right)+c .
\]

Collect the real and imaginary parts:

\[
f(w)=\Bigl(\frac{b-a}{2}+c\Bigr)
    +\,i\,\frac{\sqrt3}{2}(a+b).
\]

---

### 2.  Equate with the given value

\[
2015+2019\sqrt3\, i=
\Bigl(\frac{b-a}{2}+c\Bigr)
    +\,i\,\frac{\sqrt3}{2}(a+b).
\]

From the real part  
\[
\frac{b-a}{2}+c=2015\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad b-a=4030-2c,
\tag{1}
\]

and from the imaginary part  
\[
\frac{a+b}{2}=2019\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad a+b=4038.
\tag{2}
\]

Solve (1)–(2):

\[
\begin{aligned}
a &= 4+c,\\[2mm]
b &= 4034-c.
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 3.  Use the restriction on coefficients

Each coefficient is a real number not exceeding \(2019\):

\[
\begin{cases}
a\le 2019 &\Rightarrow c\le 2015,\\
b\le 2019 &\Rightarrow 4034-c\le 2019 \;\; \Rightarrow\;\; c\ge 2015,\\
c\le 2019 &\text{(already satisfied)}.
\end{cases}
\]

Hence \(c=2015\).  
Then  

\[
a=4+2015=2019,\qquad
b=4034-2015=2019.
\]

All three coefficients lie in the required range.

---

### 4.  Compute \(f(1)\) and its remainder mod \(1000\)

\[
f(1)=a+b+c=2019+2019+2015=6053.
\]

Dividing by \(1000\): \(6053=6\cdot1000+53\).

Therefore the remainder when \(f(1)\) is divided by \(1000\) is

\[
\boxed{53}.
\]

The equation of a digital filter is given by $y(n)=1 / 3(x(n)+x(n-1)+x(n-2))$, where $y(n)$ and $x(n)$ are, respectively, the nth samples of the output and input signals. Determine the pole(s) of the filter.

**Answer**

The difference equation is  

\[
y[n]=\frac{1}{3}\bigl(x[n]+x[n-1]+x[n-2]\bigr)\;,
\]

which is a purely **finite‑impulse‑response (FIR)** filter.  
Its transfer function is

\[
H(z)=\frac{Y(z)}{X(z)}=\frac{1}{3}\Bigl(1+z^{-1}+z^{-2}\Bigr).
\]

An FIR filter has a denominator of \(1\); therefore it has **no finite poles** in the z‑plane.  
(If one prefers to write the transfer function with a polynomial in \(z\),

\[
H(z)=\frac{z^{2}+z+1}{3\,z^{2}},
\]

which shows a double pole at \(z=0\).  In digital‑filter terminology this is usually
incorporated into the delay term, and the filter is said to have *no poles* except the
trivial pole at the origin.)

Reactant A (C10H9ClO) shows a single negative peak in its DEPT-135 spectrum. When Reactant A reacts with a Lewis acid, it undergoes an intramolecular Friedel-Crafts reaction to yield Product B, which also displays a single negative peak in its DEPT-135 spectrum. Subsequent treatment of Product B with hydrazine in the presence of NaOH results in the formation of Product C, which exhibits two negative peaks in its DEPT-135 spectrum. Upon heating Product C with N-bromosuccinimide in the presence of peroxide, it transforms into Product D, which is characterized by two peaks appearing below 60 ppm and remaining peaks above 100 ppm in its 13C-NMR spectrum.
Identify product D.
Answer Choices:
(A) 1-bromo-1,2-dihydronaphthalene
(B) 2,3-dibromo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene
(C) 2-bromo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene
(D) 2-bromonaphthalene

**Product D is 1‑bromo‑1,2‑dihydronaphthalene**  

---

### Why the other answers are impossible  

| Product | Sp‑3 carbons | 13C‑NMR expectation | Consistency with the stated spectrum |
|---------|--------------|---------------------|--------------------------------------|
| (A) 1‑bromo‑1,2‑dihydronaphthalene | 2 (C1 = CHBr ; C2 = CH₂) | two peaks < 60 ppm + 8 aryl carbons > 100 ppm | ✔︎ |
| (B) 2,3‑dibromo‑1,2,3,4‑tetrahydronaphthalene | 4 (C1 = CH₂; C2 = CBr; C3 = CBr; C4 = CH₂) | four sp‑3 peaks < 60 ppm + 6 aryl > 100 ppm | ❌ |
| (C) 2‑bromo‑1,2,3,4‑tetrahydronaphthalene | 4 (C1 = CH₂; C2 = CBr; C3 = CH₂; C4 = CH₂) | four sp‑3 peaks < 60 ppm + 6 aryl > 100 ppm | ❌ |
| (D) 2‑bromonaphthalene | 0 | 0 peaks < 60 ppm, 10 aryl > 100 ppm | ❌ |

Only **(A)** has exactly two carbons that will resonate below 60 ppm – the CH₂ and the CHBr – while all other carbons are aromatic and appear above 100 ppm.  

---

### Connecting the reagents to the product

| Step | Transformation | Why NMR fits |
|------|-----------------|--------------|
| **Reactant A (C10H9ClO)** | One CH₂ group → single negative peak (DEPT‑135) |
| **Lewis‑acid induced intramolecular Friedel–Crafts** | Form a bicyclic ketone/ester (Product B). The side‑chain CH₂ stays intact → still one negative peak. |
| **Hydrazine/NaOH** | Evokes a Beckmann‑type rearrangement/cleavage → gives **1,2‑dihydronaphthalene (Product C)**. Two saturated carbons give two negative peaks. |
| **NBS/Peroxide** | Radical bromination at the benzylic (C1) position → **1‑bromo‑1,2‑dihydronaphthalene (Product D)**. |

In **Product C** the two saturated positions (C1‑C2) give two CH₂ signals (DEPT‑135 negative). After radical bromination one of these carbons becomes CHBr; the other stays CH₂. Therefore the ¹³C spectrum of **D** shows:

- **CH₂** (≈ 30 ppm, sp‑3) → below 60 ppm  
- **CHBr** (≈ 40 – 45 ppm, sp‑3) → below 60 ppm  
- 8 aryl carbons (≈ 110‑140 ppm) → above 100 ppm  

Exactly the pattern described in the problem statement.  

Thus **Product D is 1‑bromo‑1,2‑dihydronaphthalene** – choice (A).

A set contains four numbers. The six pairwise sums of distinct elements of the set, in no particular order, are $189$ , $320$ , $287$ , $234$ , $x$ , and $y$ . Find the greatest possible value of $x+y$ .

Let the four numbers of the set be  

\[
a\le b\le c\le d .
\]

The six pairwise sums are  

\[
\begin{array}{l}
s_1=a+b,\\[2pt]
s_2=a+c,\\[2pt]
s_3=\min (a+d,\;b+c),\\[2pt]
s_4=\max (a+d,\;b+c),\\[2pt]
s_5=b+d,\\[2pt]
s_6=c+d,
\end{array}\qquad 
s_1\le s_2\le s_3\le s_4\le s_5\le s_6 .
\]

The six sums satisfy the well‑known equalities  

\[
s_1+s_6=s_2+s_5=s_3+s_4=a+b+c+d=:S. \tag{1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Maximising the sum of the two unknown sums

We are told that four of the six sums are  
\(189,234,287,320\).
Let the remaining two sums be \(x\) and \(y\), whose value we have to maximise.

Because the sequence \(\{s_i\}\) is increasing, the two largest sums are
\(s_5\) and \(s_6\); the sum of any other two sums is at most
\(s_5+s_6\).  
Hence, in order to make \(x+y\) as large as possible we must take

\[
\{x,y\}=\{s_5,s_6\}.
\]

Thus \(x+y=s_5+s_6\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Where do the four given numbers sit?

If the largest two sums are \(x\) and \(y\), the given four numbers
must occupy the first four positions:

\[
s_1=189,\qquad s_2=234,\qquad s_3=287,\qquad s_4=320 .
\]

These values are in increasing order, so this placement is
compatible with the ordering of the sums.

With these identifications, (1) gives

\[
S=s_3+s_4=287+320=607 .
\]

From (1) we also have

\[
s_5=S-s_2=607-234=373,\qquad
s_6=S-s_1=607-189=418 .
\]

Hence

\[
x+y=s_5+s_6=373+418=791 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Attainability

The numbers  

\[
a=68,\qquad b=121,\qquad c=166,\qquad d=252
\]

satisfy  

\[
a+b=189,\; a+c=234,\; b+c=287,\; a+d=320,\;
b+d=373,\; c+d=418 .
\]

Thus the multiset of the six pair–wise sums of this set is
\(\{189,234,287,320,373,418\}\),
and \(x+y=373+418=791\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  No larger value is possible

If \(x\) and \(y\) are not the two largest sums, say one of them equals
\(s_4\) or one of \(s_1,s_2\), then \(x+y\le s_5+s_6\).
Since \(s_5+s_6\) in the above configuration equals \(791\), any other
placement of the known numbers cannot give a larger sum of the two
unknown sums.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{791}
\]

In trapezoid $ABCD$ with $\overline{BC}\parallel\overline{AD}$, let $BC = 1000$ and $AD = 2008$. Let $\angle A = 37^\circ$, $\angle D = 53^\circ$, and $M$ and $N$ be the midpoints of $\overline{BC}$ and $\overline{AD}$, respectively. Find the length $MN$.

Let the trapezoid be placed with \(AD\) on the \(x\)-axis.

\[
A=(0,0),\qquad D=(2008,0)
\]

Since \(BC\parallel AD\), let  

\[
B=(x,h),\qquad C=(x+1000,h)
\]

where \(h>0\) is the height of the trapezoid.  
Then

\[
M=\text{midpoint of }BC=(x+500,\;h),\qquad 
N=\text{midpoint of }AD=(1004,\;0).
\]

---

### Using the given angles

At \(A\) the side \(AB\) makes an angle of \(37^\circ\) with the base \(AD\):

\[
\tan 37^\circ = \frac{h}{x}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad h=x\tan 37^\circ .
\]

At \(D\) the side \(CD\) makes an angle of \(53^\circ\) with the base \(AD\).  
Because \(53^\circ=90^\circ-37^\circ\), we have \(\tan 53^\circ=\cot 37^\circ=\frac1{\tan37^\circ}\).

So

\[
\tan 53^\circ =\frac{h}{2008-(x+1000)}
      =\frac{h}{1008-x}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
h=(1008-x)\tan 53^\circ .
\]

Equating the two expressions for \(h\):

\[
x\tan37^\circ=(1008-x)\tan53^\circ .
\]

Using \(\tan53^\circ=\frac1{\tan37^\circ}\),

\[
x\tan^2 37^\circ + x = 1008
      \;\Longrightarrow\;
x=\frac{1008}{1+\tan^2 37^\circ} .
\]

Thus

\[
h=x\tan37^\circ=\frac{1008\,\tan37^\circ}{1+\tan^2 37^\circ}
              =\frac{1008}{\frac{1}{\tan37^\circ}+ \tan37^\circ}
              =\frac{1008\,\tan37^\circ}{\sec^2 37^\circ}
              =1008\cos37^\circ\sin37^\circ .
\]

---

### Length \(MN\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
MN^2 &=\bigl((x+500)-1004\bigr)^2+h^2\\
     &=\bigl(x-504\bigr)^2+h^2.
\end{aligned}
\]

Insert \(x=\dfrac{1008}{1+\tan^2 37^\circ}\) and \(h=x\tan37^\circ\).
After substitution and simplifying (using \(1+\tan^2\theta=\sec^2\theta\) and
\(\tan 53^\circ=\cot 37^\circ\)) we get

\[
MN^2=\frac{504^2 (1-\tan^2 37^\circ)^2}{(1+\tan^2 37^\circ)^2}
      +\frac{[1008\,\tan37^\circ]^2}{(1+\tan^2 37^\circ)^2}
      =504^2 .
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{MN=504}.
\]

(Indeed, \(MN=\dfrac{AD-BC}{2}=\dfrac{2008-1000}{2}\).)

Let $\Gamma$ denote a curve $y=y(x)$ which is in the first quadrant and let the point $(1,0)$ lie on it. Let the tangent to $\Gamma$ at a point $P$ intersect the $y$-axis at $Y_{P}$. If $P Y_{P}$ has length 1 for each point $P$ on $\Gamma$, then which of the following options is/are correct?

(A) $y=\log _{e}\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x}\right)-\sqrt{1-x^{2}}$

(B) $x y^{\prime}+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}=0$

(C) $y=-\log _{e}\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x}\right)+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}$

(D) $x y^{\prime}-\sqrt{1-x^{2}}=0$

For a point \(P=(x,y)\) on \(\Gamma\) the tangent line is  

\[
y-y_{P}=y'(x-x_{P}), \qquad (x_{P}=x,\;y_{P}=y)
\]

Its intersection with the \(y\)-axis is obtained by setting \(x=0\):

\[
Y_{P}=(0,\;y-y'x).
\]

Hence

\[
P Y_{P}= \sqrt{(x-0)^{2}+\bigl(y-(y-y'x)\bigr)^{2}}
      =\sqrt{x^{2}+y'^{2}x^{2}}
      =x\sqrt{1+{y'}^{2}} .
\]

The condition \(P Y_{P}=1\) for every point \(P\) gives  

\[
x^{2}\bigl(1+{y'}^{2}\bigr)=1
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
y'=-\,\frac{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x}\qquad(0<x\le 1).
\]

(The negative sign is needed so that \(y>0\) for \(x<1\); with the
positive sign the curve would leave the first quadrant.)

---

### 1.  The differential equation in the options

The differential equation just obtained is  

\[
x\,y'+\sqrt{\,1-x^{2}\,}=0 .
\]

This is exactly option **(B)**.  
Option **(D)** would correspond to the opposite sign and thus cannot
produce a curve that stays in the first quadrant.

---

### 2.  Solving for \(y(x)\)

\[
\frac{dy}{dx}=-\frac{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x}, \qquad y(1)=0.
\]

Integrate:

\[
\int  dy = -\int \frac{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x}\,dx .
\]

Let \(x=\sin\theta\;(0\le\theta\le\pi/2)\),
then \(\sqrt{1-x^{2}}=\cos\theta\) and \(dx=\cos\theta\,d\theta\):

\[
-\int\frac{\cos \theta}{\sin\theta}\cos\theta\,d\theta
   =-\int\frac{\cos^{2}\theta}{\sin\theta}\,d\theta
   =-\int(\csc\theta-\sin\theta)\,d\theta
   =-\Bigl(\ln\tan\frac{\theta}{2}+\cos\theta\Bigr)+C .
\]

Returning to \(x\) (\(\cos\theta=\sqrt{1-x^{2}},\;
\tan\dfrac{\theta}{2}=\dfrac{x}{1+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}\)),

\[
y=\ln\frac{1+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x}-\sqrt{1-x^{2}}+C .
\]

Using \(y(1)=0\) gives \(C=0\). Therefore

\[
y=\boxed{\,\ln\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x}\right)-\sqrt{1-x^{2}}\,},
\]

which is exactly option **(A)**.  
Option **(C)** is the negative of this function and does **not** satisfy
the differential equation nor keep the curve in the first quadrant.

---

\[
\boxed{\text{Correct options: (A) and (B)}}
\]

Let  $ A$  be a commutative unitary ring with an odd number of elements. 

Prove that the number of solutions of the equation  $ x^2 \equal{} x$  (in  $ A$ ) divides the number of invertible elements of  $ A$ .

Let \(A\) be a finite commutative ring with identity and let  

\[
S(A)=\{x\in A\mid x^{2}=x\}\qquad\text{and}\qquad  
U(A)=\{x\in A\mid x\ \hbox{is a unit}\}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Structure of a finite commutative ring

Because \(A\) is finite, it is an Artinian ring; hence its Jacobson radical
\(J=J(A)\) is nilpotent.  
The quotient \(A/J\) is a semisimple commutative Artinian ring, therefore

\[
A/J\;\cong\;\prod_{i=1}^{m}\mathbf F_{q_i}
\tag{1}
\]

with each \(\mathbf F_{q_i}\) a finite field.  
Since \(|A|\) is odd, the order of every field \(\mathbf F_{q_i}\) is odd; hence
each \(q_i\) is an odd power of a prime.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Idempotents

Idempotents lift over nilpotent ideals.

> **Lemma.**  
> Let \(I\trianglelefteq A\) and \(I^n=0\).  
> For an idempotent \(\bar e\in A/I\) there is a unique idempotent
> \(e\in A\) with \(\bar e=e+I\).

Apply the lemma to \(I=J\).  
Thus \(e\mapsto e+J\) gives a bijection
\(S(A)\leftrightarrow S(A/J)\).

In the product of fields (1) an element is idempotent iff each component
equals \(0\) or \(1\).  Each factor \(\mathbf F_{q_i}\) has exactly two
idempotents; consequently

\[
|S(A)|=|S(A/J)|=\prod_{i=1}^{m}2=2^{m}.   \tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Units

The natural projection  
\(\pi :U(A)\to U(A/J)\) is surjective, and  
\(\ker\pi=1+J\).  Hence

\[
|U(A)|=|1+J|\;\bigl|U(A/J)\bigr|. \tag{3}
\]

Each field \(\mathbf F_{q_i}\) has \(q_i-1\) units.  
Because every \(q_i\) is odd, \(q_i-1\) is even; therefore

\[
|U(A/J)|=\prod_{i=1}^{m}(q_i-1)\quad\text{is divisible by }2^{m}. \tag{4}
\]

From (3)–(4) we obtain that \(|U(A)|\) is divisible by \(2^{m}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  The required divisibility

By (2) the number of solutions of \(x^2=x\) is \(2^{m}\).  
From (4) the number of units is a multiple of \(2^{m}\).
Hence

\[
|S(A)|=2^{m}\;\mid\;|U(A)|.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 5.  Remark on the trivial ring

If \(|A|=1\), then \(S(A)=U(A)=\{1\}\), so the statement is true
as well.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Thus, for every finite commutative unitary ring with an odd number of
elements, the number of idempotent solutions of \(x^{2}=x\) divides the
number of invertible elements.  ∎

A biologist wants to calculate the number of fish in a lake. On May 1 she catches a random sample of 60 fish, tags them, and releases them. On September 1 she catches a random sample of 70 fish and finds that 3 of them are tagged. To calculate the number of fish in the lake on May 1, she assumes that 25% of these fish are no longer in the lake on September 1 (because of death and emigrations), that 40% of the fish were not in the lake May 1 (because of births and immigrations), and that the number of untagged fish and tagged fish in the September 1 sample are representative of the total population. What does the biologist calculate for the number of fish in the lake on May 1?

The biologist would estimate **about 840 fish** were in the lake on May 1.  The calculation is

1. 75 % of the 60 marked fish survive to September, so 45 marked fish are still present.
2. 3 marked fish were caught out of 70 in September, so  
   \[
   \frac{45}{M_{\text{Sep}}}=\frac{3}{70}\;\Longrightarrow\;M_{\text{Sep}}=1050.
   \]
3. 40 % of the September population are new (births/immigration).  
   Thus 60 % of 1050 = 630 fish were present on May 1.
4. 25 % of the May population died/emigrated, so 0.75 N = 630.  
   Hence \(N = 630/0.75 = 840\).

So the biologist would conclude that the lake contained approximately **840 fish on May 1**.

A token starts at the point $(0,0)$ of an $xy$ -coordinate grid and then makes a sequence of six moves. Each move is 1 unit in a direction parallel to one of the coordinate axes. Each move is selected randomly from the four possible directions and independently of the other moves. The probability the token ends at a point on the graph of $|y|=|x|$ is $\tfrac{m}{n}$ , where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $m+n$ .

Let  

\[
a,b,c,d
\]

be the numbers of steps East, West, North and South, respectively  
(\(a,b,c,d\ge 0,\; a+b+c+d=6\)).  
After the walk

\[
x=a-b,\qquad y=c-d .
\]

The token lands on the graph of \(|y|=|x|\) iff  

\[
|a-b|=|c-d| .
\tag{1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Counting the favourable sequences

For every quadruple \((a,b,c,d)\) the number of step‑orders that realise it is

\[
\frac{6!}{a!\,b!\,c!\,d!}
\tag{2}
\]

because the steps are arranged in \(\frac{6!}{n_a!n_b!n_c!n_d!}\) ways.

Let  

\[
t=a+b,\qquad s=6-t .
\]

Then \(t\) is the total number of horizontal steps and \(s\) the number of vertical
steps.  
Put  

\[
k=|a-b|=|c-d|.
\]

For a fixed \((t,k)\) the solutions are

\[
a=\frac{t+k}{2},\qquad b=\frac{t-k}{2},
\]
\[
c=\frac{s+k}{2},\qquad d=\frac{s-k}{2}
\]

(which are integers iff \(k\) has the same parity as \(t\)).
If \(k=0\) there is one solution; if \(k>0\) there are four (sign
choices of the differences).
The quadruple therefore contributes

\[
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle\frac{ 6!}{a!\,b!\,c!\,d!}, &k=0,\\[6pt]
\displaystyle4\cdot\frac{ 6!}{a!\,b!\,c!\,d!}, &k>0 .
\end{cases}
\]

The admissible values of \((t,k)\) are

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
t & k\text{ allowed} \\ \hline
0 & 0\\
1 & 1\\
2 & 0,\;2\\
3 & 1,\;3\\
4 & 0,\;2\\
5 & 1\\
6 & 0
\end{array}
\]

(only values with the same parity as \(t\) are possible).

Adding the contributions for every case:

\[
\begin{aligned}
t=0,k=0&:\;20\\
t=1,k=1&:\;240\\
t=2,k=0&:\;180\\
t=2,k=2&:\;240\\
t=3,k=1&:\;720\\
t=3,k=3&:\;80\\
t=4,k=0&:\;180\\
t=4,k=2&:\;240\\
t=5,k=1&:\;240\\
t=6,k=0&:\;20
\end{aligned}
\]

The total number of favourable sequences is  

\[
20+240+180+240+720+80+180+240+240+20=2160 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Probability

There are \(4^6 = 4096\) possible sequences of six moves.  
Hence

\[
P=\frac{2160}{4096}
   =\frac{135}{256}\qquad(\text{reduced as }135,256\text{ are coprime}).
\]

Thus \(m=135,\;n=256\) and

\[
m+n=135+256= \boxed{391}.
\]

Alice Czarina continues until there are no more rocks in the pile. Let $p$ be the probability that the number of rocks left in the pile after each round is a multiple of 5. If $p$ is of the form $5^{a} \cdot 31^{b} \cdot \frac{c}{d}$, where $a, b$ are integers and $c, d$ are positive integers relatively prime to $5 \cdot 31$, find $a+b$.

Let \(m_0 = \frac{2015}{5}=403\).

If the pile contains \(5m\) rocks, the only choices of \(k\) that leave a multiple of \(5\) are the multiples of \(5\) themselves.  
Hence

\[
P_m=\Pr(\text{stay multiple of }5 \text{ until empty}\mid m)
     =\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{1}{5m}\,P_{m-j}
\]
